intro: Sinapis alpina, commonly known as alpine mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring slender stems and small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and covered in fine hairs, while its seed pods are slender and elongated. Sinapis alpina thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine meadows and grasslands.
